awd_titl_txt: Purine catabolites as inducers of bacterial gene expression
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall goal of this project is to understand mechanisms by which bacterial pathogens adapt to a plant host environment, an adaptation that is essential for bacterial survival and virulence. Knowing such mechanisms is required for efforts to control disease progression. When a bacterial plant pathogen infects a host, a tug-of-war ensues in which the plant host aims to defend itself against the pathogen; the bacterium in turn responds, often subverting host defenses by utilizing host-derived signals to trigger expression of traits that promote survival and virulence. This project focuses on mechanisms by which bacteria detect and respond to such host-derived signals. In addition, the program integrates research and teaching by offering the opportunity for both graduate and undergraduate students to acquire research experience and proficiency in modern molecular biology techniques. Graduate students will be integral to developing these research projects and in disseminating results. For undergraduate students, many of whom will be recruited from programs that promote inclusion and diversity, the opportunities for independent research will complement their regular course curriculum, prepare them for advanced studies, and contribute to the development of a competitive STEM workforce.

Hosts produce reactive oxygen species as a defense against a bacterial infection. One of the enzymes responsible for this oxidative burst is xanthine dehydrogenase, which converts hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to urate. The first objective of this project is to address the hypothesis that the xanthine and urate that are produced by host plants during a bacterial infection function as diffusible signals to induce differential gene expression in the bacterium. The second goal is to investigate the role of the transcription factor PecS in sensing xanthine and urate and controlling gene expression. A combination of RNA-seq and ChIP-seq will be implemented to identify the PecS regulon, and phenotypes of pecS mutant strains predicted from RNA-seq data will be determined. Focusing on the plant pathogen Agrobacterium fabrum, the virulence of wild-type and pecS deletion mutant strains will be compared. Defining host-derived signals and the mechanisms by which these diffusible messengers trigger expression of virulence-associated genes in plant pathogens will ultimately facilitate development of antibacterial agents.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: When a bacterial pathogen infects a plant host, the plant defends itself by producing an assortment of compounds, some of which are toxic to the bacterium. This in turn elicits a response from the bacterium in which plant-derived metabolites are detected by bacterial transcription factors, an interaction that leads to increased expression of virulence genes. Metabolites that accumulate in response to a bacterial infection include urate and xanthine, which derive from degradation of purine bases that are released from DNA and RNA. The objective of this work was to address the specific hypotheses that the bacterial transcription factor PecS regulates genes whose expression promotes bacterial fitness in a host environment and that the plant-derived metabolites urate and xanthine modulate such virulence gene expression by binding directly to PecS. A comprehensive understanding of molecular mechanisms by which bacterial plant pathogens adapt to the host environment may inform approaches to treat infection.

Bacterial pathogens under investigation included Agrobacterium fabrum, which infects a wide range of plant species. A. fabrum PecS controls gene expression in response to xanthine and urate, and it regulates properties such as motility, which is required for the bacteria to reach plant wound sites, and community behaviors such as the formation of biofilms in which the bacteria adhere to each other and to certain surfaces. PecS is also involved in resistance to oxidative stress, which is important for the bacteria to survive plant defenses in response to infection. These data suggest that PecS mediates A. fabrum fitness during its transition from the soil environment to the host plant.

Burkholderia thailandensis encodes a PecS protein named MftR, which also binds directly to both urate and xanthine. MftR was found to regulate approximately 400 genes, including genes associated with virulence. Consistent with the ability of MftR to repress expression of several virulence genes, bacterial cells lacking MftR exhibit greater virulence on onion. MftR controls a number of traits, which would be expected to enhance virulence, such as motility, survival under conditions of low oxygen, and biofilm formation. MftR also regulates several genes encoding proteins required for synthesis of secondary metabolites, which are generally produced to enhance bacterial fitness. Taken together, these data indicate that MftR controls several properties, which promote bacterial survival in a host environment.

Successful host invasion is associated with activation of gene regulatory networks that operate to control production of virulence factors and enhance fitness. Our data suggest that PecS proteins function at the top of a hierarchy of regulators that control expression of multiple genes linked to enhanced fitness. The discovery that urate and xanthine, which are produced in infected plants, function to induce gene expression in a set of bacterial species that encode a PecS protein has implications for understanding activation of gene regulatory networks during adaptation to a host environment.

BROADER IMPACTS: Broader impacts of this award focused on graduate and undergraduate student training. Several graduate students received training under this award, they presented their research at national meetings, and they published research and review articles. Three graduate students successfully defended their PhD dissertations. Seven undergraduate students participated in research; three presented their research at national meetings and five were co-authors on published research articles. All former trainees have continued their academic or professional careers; PhD graduates have secured postdoctoral positions or jobs in industry and former undergraduate researchers have enrolled in graduate school, medical school, or medical scientist training programs.
